results.content:
Pluses:
* Mark is a great instructor, he explains things clear and enthusiastically and doesn't get you bored. He keeps his videos short and to the point, which is great and perhaps it's why the course doesn't have longer hours of lectures.
* The lab exercises are really useful on implementing the materials learned. I started coding with CodeAcademy and while it has a great interactive interface, I had no idea what to do afterward while staring at the empty text editor. So this "old-school" way of learning helped me to gain more confidence writing and maneuvering in "real life" environment.

Minuses:
* A bit outdated. The course is (I assume) about two years old, which is a lot in terms of web developing in general, and HTML in particular. Some of the topics learned are irrelevant now with HTML5&CSS3 being more implemented and replacing the old ways of website layouts.
* I was quite disappointed by the lack of support from the instructor. Your question may very well remain unanswered on this course, unless someone is taking the course simultaneously along with you and can help you out.
* Materials doesn't go as deep as you might expected.
* Unfortunately, it doesn't get you to become a certified web developer. More in depth knowledge and a few more languages will probably get you there, so it does provides you with a good basics to become one.


In conclusion, with Mark as the instructor I believe this course has a great potential to be one of the best ways of learning web developing. Seems like he does have a lot of experience in the field, and knows how to pass it quite well. But the minuses mentioned cannot be ignored, so I believe the course can be improved and updated to get a 5/5.

results.content: First of all, the title is misleading, you will have to pay extra to become a certified web developer. Then you have to keep in mind that this is a pretty basic course. The material is good and the labs at the end of each section force you to wrap your head around the recently learned material, but there are a few mistakes in the course material that haven't been corrected even after students pointed those mistakes out to the instructor. Mark Lassoff is a pleasant instructor (his typing skills could use some improvement, what's up with him not using shortcuts?), but I think there are better courses out there on Udemy.

results.content: This was the first "comprehensive" course I worked through in my journey towards a career in web development. It does focus on HTML4 and XHTML for the markup portions, but the content is helpful in spite of the industry's transition to HTML5. The teching is pverall helpful, but not extraordinary. I actually wonder if taking and passing LTP's certification exam would really mean anything to a proespective employer? (One oddity across several lectures is hearing Mark's tendency to swallow loudly. I thought it was kind of gross... Just an observation though.)

results.content:
I  haven't touched a line of code since childhood, when I attempted to format floppy disks on our no-name OS computer. My work history has been primarily in education and healthcare, neither of which have required coding. Needless to say, I was a little anxious after hitting "Purchase". Since completing the course over the span of one month, I don't have a single regret. 

Mark is a great teacher and made the transition into coding pretty smooth. I typed along with him during the lessons, which I would strongly recommend for anyone considering the course. As a person of  simple tastes, I most enjoyed the HTML and CSS lessons. Some of the PHP/mySQL went over my head, but I'm sure another run-through of the material would fix that issue. I really like the fact that lab exercises are included at the end of each chapter - they get you to apply what you've learned and this makes it easier to remember the material in the future.

I've already signed up for another course from LearnToProgram and am looking forward to expanding my knowledge of programming languages.

results.content: This is a great course for beginners to HTML and CSS (am halfway through and up to Javascript). I've been working through another online course that was significantly more expensive, and was still left with no real understanding of the code and in fact what I was doing. Mark's course is different! He makes sure that everything is explained thoroughly - even if it takes a few views of the video to grasp the concepts, the information given is thorough. Mark's style is quick and to the point - no waiting around for him to type and he doesn't go off-topic. Mark also is a very experienced developer and you can tell that he is committed to quality - you will pick up some very good habits from him! Highly recommended for beginners and semi-beginners who would like a more in-depth understanding of web development. The only downside is - you aren't automatically a certified web developer at the end of the course - you do have to pay to sit an external exam through LearntoProgram.tv. Slightly false advertising but the course is so worthwhile I'm not concerned. Thanks!

results.content:
I enjoyed the first couple of sections, but things started falling apart in the Javascript section. The instruction seemed light compared to what was asked in the assignments. Also, I am a bit confused because the course jumps from exercise 41 Javascript Promises to "Section 4: (OLDER- For Reference) HTML 5 Specialist: First Steps in HTML".
The course overview mentions a PHP/MySQL section, but I don't see that section (aside from OLDER- For Reference material). 
I am not particularly concerned about getting the PHP/MySQL section, but I do want to do everything necessary to receive the "Certified Web Development Professional credential".
Inquiries as to whether I have met the requirements for the overall credential, and if not, where to find the outstanding materials have gone unanswered. Is this course being discontinued as the lack of response to course questions suggests? I can not recommend this course to anyone in its current state.

results.content:
I purchased this course about a month ago and I have to say it has been the single best investment I've made in anything over the past number of years. I run an online business myself where my company mostly sells on marketplaces such as Amazon and eBay etc but I really wanted to learn how to program and develop for the web as really this is where the future of all things commerce is going. So I saw this course and after the introduction video I was sold.

The course is divided into a number of sections as you can see if you browse the course contents. The nice thing about the course is that you can learn each of the sections one by one or you could dip in and out of sections as you please as each section is self contained.

I found that after completing the course I was able to develop a pretty professional site as well as knowing what skills I need to develop to become a true web professional. The nice thing is that after just one month of this course people I know have seen my work and asked me to develop sites for them. This is amazing and really justifies the money you'll have spent on the course.

Also Mark is a great instructor and I've actually emailed a few times with some extra questions etc and he has responded within minutes - not even hours! It's great to have a web professional pretty much on demand to help answer further questions you may have.

My advice...get obsessed and get learning!!

results.content: I will tell you why I stated my subject header this way. For starters, two months before this was available on Udemy. The same class, maybe with a little less comparatively. Regardless, it was through a similar site, very reputable because of the name. etc... I paid for that on sale. No biggie. The description started HTML, XHTM, CSS, JAVAQUERY, JAVASCRIPT A& PHP. Here is why I am writing this review..Two major components. One. major lack of communication on the instructor's side. I have asked for help, both on here and through other venues, like the other site. Finally I emailed this instructor.Two. How hard is it to be up to date? If you are the self proclaimed guru. Then why are you still on HTML 1 -3? An update to the times would make this pop. The instructor takes so much pride, that he failed to update this course with the title CERTIFIED WEB DEVELOPER. There are some amazing instructors on Udemy who teach the same curriculum for Web Development. The XHTML is not even used, I understand you got to start from the rudiments, but come on. That combines two major proponents in making this class a success. Only issue. This same instructor is all over the web. So he is money hungry and it shows. He could give two pigeons about anyone who is taking this class. The other part to this. I had emailed Mark several times and to no avail would I get a response. Finally 8 months later I get I am sorry....check out my new class on learn to program. tv. etc...or  whatever. Jus take this and shut up kinda attitude. Here is a discount.  What? I asked why he was not responding to the questions on the discussion? Seriously, this guy is so far up his own behind that everyone who has taken this course can easily agree that not a single person got help. If they did, I apologize in advance.  I am only giving it two stars when really, it deserves a negative one! I am not kidding. I really just want my money back at this juncture. I got burned twice and although I took most of his course. I can not use it most of it because it is archaic. IT is pointless...go to Rob Perceival. He knows how to teach a course and to update his material with the times. Enough on him. Back to this instructor. I will give him this. He is thorough like a preacher and he definitely does not "cut-corners" on his teaching. His approach can get redundant, but he comes from a different school of thought and I guess, we all need to appreciate that. All in all, this could be a great class. Yet, the instructor's failure to connect and be updated, makes for this class to really not be worth anyone's time. Unless you are behind the times. In that case, jump on in to 1999. Welcome!

The course gives a general perspective of web details and has more deep involvement in the PHP and MYSQL areas, but even then many of the course references and tasks seem like they were written in a few minutes, not to mention some tasks do not have attached files and the course instructor seems absent... Make sure that the courses are solid before producing more!

results.content: This is a really great course for beginners.  It goes through many different techniques and concepts that will have you saying "Oh, that's how they do that!".  The only thing that I feel could improve this course would be to incorporate a couple of "tying together" lessons that show how one can use the separate tools in unison to create a final product.  Right now this program is basically several separate courses in HTML/CSS, Javascript, and PHP/SQL bundled into one package.  You definitely become comfortable with the basics in all languages, but I am still a bit confused as to when I should use, say, Javascript vs. PHP in a particular situation.  If Mark would add something to address that in this course I'd say it's pretty much perfect.  Thanks for your hard work!

results.content:
When I first started this course, it was well explained and the labs helped practice recent information. I gave the course a five-star rating. 

Since I've started the Javascript section, I've been fighting the homework because I want to record all of the steps as I learn them, which doesn't seem to be the point of the homework. The "answer sheet" only shows the very last few stages of instructions, which gets incredibly confusing when I'm stuck earlier on. Being able to compare between previous steps and new steps has always been the best way for me to learn coding, so I am having to deviate from the homework instructions simply to keep the older information with the new. 

I'm still glad I have gotten this course, because I am learning, but having to fight what should be fairly straightforward labs is very frustrating.

results.content:
I purchased this course about a month ago. The things I like about this course are:

-Mark presents the information clear manner.

-Mark has a knack for breaking down complex material into easily digestible bits. 

-Everything is broken down into sections, and everything can be downloaded and reviewed after each lecture.

-Each chapter has a lab that can be completed in order to reinforce material. That really helps reinforce the material learned.

Answer keys are provided so that you can see how well you wrote your code. 

I find my self challenged and engaged for the first time in a long time.

-Its very much like going to class.

In short, this is a great course and I actually look forward to studying HTML,CSS, Javascript, PHP, and MySQL. I would recommend this course to anyone looking to learn web development.

results.content:
The content is clear and concise, lot's of little details, which is always useful.

UPDATE: I've gotten to the Javascript part of the course, and I'm really enjoying myself. I updated my rating to 5 stars.

UPDATE 2: So far so good, I really like the content. The audio quality does shift a tiny bit, it's not that distracting but it's something I noticed.

I dropped one half star because on arrays, two loops were used. The for-in loops and the for loop. I would have liked a comparison between those loops. I compared both on my own, but I would have liked to see the comparison in the video. Because the regular for loop displayed empty elements in the array, writing out the "undefined" where the for-in loop skips empty elements. I know it's a small thing, but it's actually an error I've run into often enough as a student. :)

This program was worth every cent I paid into it. I didn't feel like I was wasting time watching worthless videos, I felt guided through the learning process by someone, Mark, who spoke my language and made everything simple and easy for me to understand and digest.

The foundations for all of the program languages and techniques were well executed and poignant in what I was hoping to accomplish by paying for this class. I am glad I finally found something worth investing in!

Using Mark's videos as a baseline, I'm looking forward to (and already have) working my way through many more courses.

results.content:
Mark delivers the basics clearly and accurately but doesn't go into many detailed examples or any examples to tie the Javascript and PHP sections together: it's in this respect that this course being 3 courses combined shows most. Further reading would definitely be required before you could make full use of the knowledge gained while undertaking the course. 

It would have been nice if Mark had gone into more detail about creating layouts for pages in a manner that would be consistent across pages on your site.

Overall, the course is easy to follow and, so far as my usage has gone so far, accurate. However, expect to do more reading around the subjects to be able to fully implement them in a website.

results.content:
This course was a good start into something I was familiar with but not fully versed in. I am a graphic designer with interest into doing more web design. Although the latter half of the course went extensively into beginner fundamentals for web development, it starts to stray away less from design and into development. 

I definitely think this course is a good intro for web dev. Am i confident I could be a developer at this point, Not really. But like I said, Im interested more in design and less in back end. 

If there was one critique, it would be in the Javascript, PHP, MYSQL portion of the course. There isn't too much definition as to where these setups apply to the web, only how to create them. But again if you are a studied developer that would probably be something you already know. 

Im excited to continue using UDEMY however in some of their other courses focusing mostly in design.

After getting a degree in web development I have taken this course. Your probably thinking "Is this course worth the money?", in my opinion it is well worth the money. I wish Mark could have taught all the code courses that I had to take while earning my degree.

I earned my degree Summa Cum Laude, which means in the top 5% of my class and I must admit that I have learned things in this course that were vague in my formal education. So I reccommend that if you desire to learn web development and have the will to keep pushing on complicated subjects, take this course. It is well worth the money. This is my opinion and it is freely given.

Gregg S. Hasenjaeger

results.content:
Coming into the course, I knew the basics of HTML and just a smidgen of CSS and JavaScript. PHP/MySQL was entirely new to me. Mark was a good instructor; explanations were clear. The pace of the course was appropriate--most assignments were very easy extensions of the lecture content, but a couple were tough enough that I got stuck for days (CSS) or even weeks (PHP). Working through the frustrating bits made it rewarding and also proved this was real content, not fluff. Getting questions answered was a little hit-and-miss, but support was acceptable given how inexpensive the course was. From here I've moved on to Mark's AJAX course. 

How much do you learn? More than enough to put your own website together with interactive content, though I think getting hired to do it professionally from just this class would be a stretch. It is well suited to the hobbyist/freelance web developer crowd.

results.content:
After completing this course, I would not dare calling myself a "Certified Web Developer".

However this course have given me great insight into a before closed and mysterious world, and I am confident enough to now change the code on my Wordpress website.

The most useful part of this course was, to me, the section about HTML and CSS, which will help me a great deal onwards.

The Javascript section gives a good look into how these small applications can be made on a website, but can only serve as an inspiration for me to learn even more.

The PHP section is by far the hardest to get, however it made me look at web pages like facebook with different eyes.

After completing this course I am ready to learn much more general and Web Programming!

My only critiques of the course are these:

1. Many of the php and some of the Javascript Labs, are simply too hard to solve with the information given in the preceding videos.

2. Often the solutions of the Labs require knowledge from the previous sections, which can be hard to remember and retrieve if you do not want the re-watch old videos.

A solution to my critique number 2, would be to make a short written recap in the end of each section of what was learned  also including the code, then it would be easier to retrieve that information later on.

results.content:
First of all, Mark is a good teacher. If you have no computer background like me this is a great basic foundation course and I highly recommend it!

In that case why only three stars? Well, the course is being advertised as a become web developer, that has a wonderful sound to it and I expected this to be an integrated course. However it is only a disjointed collection of separate classes for HTML, CSS, JavaScript and PHP. All great classes, but completely separate. For example in the last PHP section there is not even a mention of use with JavaScript. The best lecture and example by far is chapter 28 in the PHP section which really is chapter 9 in the PHP stand alone section. Yes, you need the understanding on of HTML to follow that brilliant chapter but that is not a unified course make. 

Also, the wamp server simulator is nice, but it would be nice to get instruction and recommendation on how to choose or use a real server where to develop our own website, this is after all the meaning of being a developer,  though that maybe could be next class...

So in short, good professor, good material, lazy not integrated format, but worth it for the begging starting from scratch like me.

results.content:
Prior to taking this course, I was pretty clueless about web development and, like most noob's, was pretty intimidated when I saw or thought about having to deal with code.  I've been powering through the course for the last few days and I so much more confident than I did before, and moreover, I find that knowing these front-end basics has empowered me to understand the logic of back-end code so much better.

Mark is a very clear, concise, and knowledgeable instructor, and his approach is both friendly and approachable.  I'm so glad that I stumbled upon this course when looking for resources to simply customize the CSS in a WordPress theme.  I feel like I can do SO much more than that and it's all thanks to Mark and his well thought out lectures and assignments.

If I had any criticism, it'd be that I wish he would either update the course for HTML5 and CSS6 or develop a new course delving into those topics.  It'd also be great if he added lectures that spoke to integrating the different elements with the back-end.  Given his skills as a lecturer, I would definitely be willing to pay even more money to have him deliver that knowledge.

Bottom line: If you have any aspirations to seriously work in a tech organization, in design, or alongside programmers, do yourself a favor and take this course.  You won't regret it!

results.content:
To be clear, I am enjoying this course and am looking forward to completing it/earning my certification(s). To that end, I'm happy to change this review, but there are some things that need to be fixed first. Here's my breakdown:

The Bad: 
- I haven't gotten a response to any of my questions from the last week, except for the response to this review.
- I haven't received any feedback or acceptance of my completed exercises.
- The course page is not clear on which sections need to be completed for certification. According to FTV's answers to this question in the Q&A section, only sections 1-3 are needed. To that end, however, what about a PHP section required for certification? I thought a PHP certificate was also offered per the course.
-  Several videos are missing the resource documents containing the assignments required for certification. Based on the Q&A section of the course, it has been this way for a few weeks.
- The course page is not clear on how certifications are issued (i.e., do we earn the HTML5 cert once we've submitted the exercises for HTML5 or after we've completed all the sections).
- There are issues with the course resource files (i.e., there is no link to the Dropbox submission page for the assignment, the PDF comes up blank, etc.)
- The course page is disorganized and there is a lot of outdated content. To be fair, it is clear that the course has evolved a lot since its inception, but the current course overview, announcements, and content layout are very hard to navigate. 

The Good:
- Mark is a good instructor and the videos are easy to follow
- If using a method that would be considered "not best practice" in an video, Mark is careful to point this out. (i.e., if using inline CSS, Mark mentions that the best practice is typically to use an external stylesheet)
- There is a lot of extra content to reference, if needed
- The lab exercises are effective and pretty fun

results.content_html:
To be clear, I am enjoying this course and am looking forward to completing it/earning my certification(s). To that end, I'm happy to change this review, but there are some things that need to be fixed first. Here's my breakdown:

The Bad:
- I haven't gotten a response to any of my questions from the last week, except for the response to this review.
- I haven't received any feedback or acceptance of my completed exercises.
- The course page is not clear on which sections need to be completed for certification. According to FTV's answers to this question in the Q&A section, only sections 1-3 are needed. To that end, however, what about a PHP section required for certification? I thought a PHP certificate was also offered per the course.
- Several videos are missing the resource documents containing the assignments required for certification. Based on the Q&A section of the course, it has been this way for a few weeks.
- The course page is not clear on how certifications are issued (i.e., do we earn the HTML5 cert once we've submitted the exercises for HTML5 or after we've completed all the sections).
- There are issues with the course resource files (i.e., there is no link to the Dropbox submission page for the assignment, the PDF comes up blank, etc.)
- The course page is disorganized and there is a lot of outdated content. To be fair, it is clear that the course has evolved a lot since its inception, but the current course overview, announcements, and content layout are very hard to navigate.

The Good:
- Mark is a good instructor and the videos are easy to follow
- If using a method that would be considered "not best practice" in an video, Mark is careful to point this out. (i.e., if using inline CSS, Mark mentions that the best practice is typically to use an external stylesheet)
- There is a lot of extra content to reference, if needed
- The lab exercises are effective and pretty fun

results.content:
I was originally really impressed, but when you start to get into the courses things become really unclear. There are a large amount of courses here that are not required to complete, and the real certificate is not done through Udemy, but is acquired by submitting files to a drop box. This makes the whole Udemy progress tracker not apply to where you are in the courses, further adding to the confusion. The instructors respond to very few of the questions in the Q&A section and it often seems like there is a hint of announce in their answers. 

The workshop sections are rough too. The workshop sometimes doesn't seem to match the lecture content very well, especially in the JavaScript section. I am finding myself switching over to other platforms to learn how to do what is in the workshop. There are also formatting, spelling, and grammatical errors through out. The wording in the workshops is also fairly vague, this sometimes makes it difficult for me to determine what is required to pass. This has caused me to have to go back and redo some content upon reviewers request.

I get very inconsistently timed responses from the reviewer after submitting my workshops for a section. Sometimes I get a response within hours, sometimes it takes weeks. I am fine with waiting, and understand things take time, but at least keep me in the loop with what is happening. I have to occasionally check-in because I feel like my submissions are berried in an inbox somewhere. 

I purchased this because it was on a limited time sale thinking I was getting a deal, but now I see this course on sale all the time... Seriously?

The design of their certificates are very sub-par. I wish it looked more official and professional. I actually ended up not hanging mine up in my office.

I am thankful for learning, but I just wish some of these basic things were a little better smoothed out. Most certainly not worth $99, maybe worth $10..

results.content:
I knew a lot of the material this course starts off with. Some of it is available without having to purchase a course. The exercises started off somewhat easy, and I did not think I was going to get what I thought I was going to get when I purchased this course. I thought I just wasted money. I stuck with the course anyway because this course is incredibly well organized. I found myself picking up a tip here and there. What really worked for me in this course is common tasks are used as examples. The course does not cover every single detail and element.  

By the end of the javascript section I learned enough to build a dynamic document outlining steps to do tasks at work that is more complicated than what mail merge options I have run into can offer because the body of the message also needs to change depending on data input. No more need to cut and paste from several sources and/or accidentally overwriting a static document. I have a smart form that asks for information once and outputs everything the employee needs to process the order complete with email subjects, messages, signatures, and case information. A task that use to take up to 40 minutes can now be done in about 12 minutes. That's just taking advantage of client side processing.

This is a great course, and if you put the work into it this course is really everything it says it is.

But fashion and versions will always be a moving target.

August 28, 2017

results.content:
A great introduction to programming for raw beginners. However, if you already know how to program and just want to learn a new language, this might not be the course for you.

The instructor is prone to making mistakes (typos) which sometimes provide convenient opportunities for further explanation and sometimes are just frustrating. Some lessons could be better scripted. 

Some of these lessons feel a little dated. The HTML lessons are based on HTML 4 and the PHP SQL lessons use deprecated  functions.

results.content:
Feedback for the course (at lecture 16 now) - - Do we need 2 lectures for HTML comments which is so simple ? This says it succinctly-

But this line will appear as a paragraph

- No project oriented approach. Please give the learner more motivation and a sense of accomplishment, no matter how small. You could combine some lectures into a project. Eg. Hi ! In lectures 1-15 we will learn enough create a simple website that shows you pics of 5 tourist places, their descriptions and costs for stay (in tabular form) etc. Not much, but its your first step ! - How about some notes/slides for lectures or combinations thereof ? Murach's HTML/CSS does this and I might just switch over to that book if the coming lectures are not good enough. $30 only ! - Is there a folder with all course files arranged in proper order ? Looking at this course, I think I would be better off with books, forums and google.
